ygData.subject: Re: Warriors vs Hybrids
ygData.msgSnippet: These are good points.  Defensively the warrior needs no more twinking, but offensively I think they do - specialization of some sort would work well I think,
ygData.messageBody:
These are good points. Defensively the warrior needs no more twinking, but
offensively I think they do - specialization of some sort would work well I
think, reducing delay and increasing damage (double mayhaps) on a particular
weapon.

> ----------
> From: Jynxx[SMTP:Jynxx@...]
> Reply To: warriors_eq@onelist.com
> Sent: Wednesday, June 16, 1999 4:36 AM
> To: warriors_eq@onelist.com
> Subject: Re: [warriors_eq] Warriors vs Hybrids
>
> From: "Jynxx" <Jynxx@...>
>
> IMHO making the warriors defensive capabilities is just the opposite way
> to
> go. Warriors are already the best in the game for defense. It's just the
> offensive part of it that gets me. Since when were warriors only tanks? In
> almost any other RPG I've ever played, warriors kicked arse on the same
> level with just about any other class. Lets look at console RPGs for a
> sec.
> Final Fantasy VII is a perfect example. Sure summons and spells did about
> 9999 damage at high levels, but you also had special ATTACKS (called limit
> breaks) that did comparable damage, if not the same. Not to mention that a
> regular attck did about half that damage anyways. But in EQ we don't even
> get HALF of the damage casters get. A caster comes in and hits a mob for,
> what, 1200? Does any warrior here do 600 damage in the same amount of
> time?
> 500? Hell even 300? that's not even 1/4 the damage a caster can do. It
> reminds me of playing AD & D in a tournament where I was the only fighter
> among 10 other Wizards. They always came in and blasted everything with
> spells and all I did was take the hits. But guess what? When we got to
> some
> Drow or something I was the one killing everything since their spells
> didn't
> work as good all of a sudden. But even then I could do comparable damage.
> Lets say they cast Fireball...good spell in AD&D. 6d6 +1/level damage. So
> a
> caster of 20th level can do 56 points of damage with one fireball to a
> LARGE
> group. But with my +3 Vorpal weapon and girdle of storm giant strength,
> I'd
> kick his arse in damage. 2 attacks per round my damage all total is 46 per
> round. That breaks down like this: +3 Vorpal Sword is 1d8+3, then my storm
> giant strentgh (24) adds +12 to damage, making maximum damage 23 per
> attack,
> twice a round. That's not including the random effects of the vorpal
> weapon.
> Anytime I get a critical strike (20 on a d20) it automatically chops off
> the
> opponents head, killing him instantly. I'm not trying to compare the
> virtues
> of AD&D to EQ, because the last thing the world needs is someone trying to
> clone the rules again. What I am doing is showing an example that the game
> CAN be balanced for each class. The damage a caster gets can blow up an
> entire group (i've seen it take out over 30 monsters) whereas a fighter is
> for one-on-one melee combat, but they both can do about the same damage
> PER
> MONSTER at the same level. Maybe I am just rambling....
>
> Jynxx
